name: Mostly Harmless Econometrics
author: Joshua D. Angrist & Jörn-Steffen Pischke
description: THE bible of applied econometrics. Covers regression, IV, DiD, and RDD with focus on clean identification. Nobel laureate Angrist's practical guide to credible causal inference.
summary: This is the definitive guide to applied econometrics, covering regression, instrumental variables, difference-in-differences, and regression discontinuity designs. Co-authored by 2021 Nobel laureate Joshua Angrist, it emphasizes practical identification strategies.
use_cases: applying econometric techniques to policy evaluation

What is regression discontinuity design?

name: The Cold Start Problem
author: Andrew Chen
description: How tech's most successful products solved the 'cold start problem' using network effects. By the former head of rider growth at Uber and a16z general partner.

name: Moneyball: The Art of Winning an Unfair Game
author: Michael Lewis
description: The book that launched sports analytics into mainstream consciousness. Chronicles how the Oakland A's used statistical analysis to compete against wealthier teams, fundamentally changing baseball's approach to player evaluation.

name: The Book: Playing the Percentages in Baseball
author: Tom Tango, Mitchel Lichtman, Andrew Dolphin
description: The technical bible of baseball analytics. Covers lineup optimization, platoon splits, clutch hitting, and defensive positioning with rigorous statistical analysis that practitioners actually use.

name: Basketball on Paper
author: Dean Oliver
description: Introduced the Four Factors framework for basketball analytics: shooting, turnovers, rebounding, and free throws. The foundational text for understanding basketball through statistics.

name: Sprawlball: A Visual Tour of the New Era of the NBA
author: Kirk Goldsberry
description: Modern basketball analytics with exceptional data visualization. Shows how the three-point revolution transformed NBA strategy through shot charts and spatial analysis.

name: Mathletics: How Gamblers, Managers, and Sports Enthusiasts Use Mathematics in Baseball, Basketball, and Football
author: Wayne L. Winston
description: The classroom standard for sports analytics, endorsed by Daryl Morey as 'perfect for someone seeking a general overview.' Covers multiple sports with accessible mathematical explanations.

name: Playbooks and Checkbooks: An Introduction to the Economics of Modern Sports
author: Stefan Szymanski
description: The best introductory text for sports economics—'lively, literate, lucid, and edifying' (Andrew Zimbalist). Covers labor markets, franchise values, stadium subsidies, and competitive balance.

name: Soccernomics
author: Simon Kuper, Stefan Szymanski
description: Applies economic analysis to global football. Covers why England loses, optimal penalty kick strategy, the economics of hosting World Cups, and how to buy football success.

name: Handbook on the Economics of Sport
author: Wladimir Andreff, Stefan Szymanski (eds.)
description: Comprehensive academic reference with 86 chapters covering every aspect of sports economics: labor markets, league design, broadcasting, betting, doping, and the Olympic Games.

name: Loss Models: From Data to Decisions
author: Stuart A. Klugman, Harry H. Panjer, Gordon E. Willmot
description: The definitive actuarial textbook covering loss distributions, credibility, simulation, and risk measures. Used for SOA Exam STAM preparation and professional practice.

name: Actuarial Mathematics for Life Contingent Risks
author: David C.M. Dickson, Mary R. Hardy, Howard R. Waters
description: Modern approach to life insurance mathematics covering survival models, life tables, premium calculation, and reserving. Standard text for SOA exams.

name: Regression Modeling with Actuarial and Financial Applications
author: Edward W. Frees
description: Bridges actuarial science and modern statistics with focus on regression for insurance applications. Covers GLMs, credibility, and longitudinal data.

name: Handbook of Insurance
author: Georges Dionne (ed.)
description: Comprehensive academic reference covering insurance economics theory and empirical research. 30 chapters on adverse selection, moral hazard, regulation, and corporate insurance.

name: Financial Economics of Insurance
author: Ralph S.J. Koijen, Motohiro Yogo
description: New framework analyzing insurance companies through modern asset pricing theory. Covers life insurance, variable annuities, and systemic risk in insurance.

name: Computational Actuarial Science with R
author: Arthur Charpentier (ed.)
description: Practical guide to actuarial computing covering simulation, GLMs, loss reserving, and mortality modeling with complete R code examples.

name: Predictive Modeling Applications in Actuarial Science
author: Edward W. Frees, Richard A. Derrig, Glenn Meyers (eds.)
description: Two-volume set covering machine learning applications in insurance. Volume 1 covers methods, Volume 2 covers case studies in pricing, underwriting, and reserving.

name: Statistical Foundations of Actuarial Learning and its Applications
author: Mario V. Wuthrich, Michael Merz
description: Bridges traditional actuarial methods and modern machine learning. Covers neural networks for pricing, telematics, and interpretability in insurance models.

name: The INSURTECH Book
author: Sabine VanderLinden, Shân Millie, Nico Anderson
description: Industry overview of digital disruption in insurance. Covers blockchain, IoT, AI applications, and business model innovation from 80+ InsurTech executives.

name: Navigating Insurtech
author: Manh Kaenprakhamroy
description: Practical guide to building InsurTech ventures covering product development, distribution, regulation, and scaling from the CEO of Bolttech.
